On 9/7/06, Tim Hardy <yahoo@...> wrote:
>
> Hi isaachanstar
>
> I'm assuming you know the basics but just in case you don't I'll briefly
> summarise. Write your plug-in tests in a second plug-in project to the
> one under test, export the packages from the first to make them visible
> and run the tests as JUnit plug-in tests to let PDE launch an Eclipse
> runtime for you in which the tests will be run. Warning, this is slow!


One  additional suggestion - make your plugin a plugin fragment of the
original plugin. That way test cases are loaded in the context of the
original plugin. With a plugin fragment objects that have same package gain
package level access. As a result many more of our classes and methods are
package level (vs. public). So they're not exposed as an official API but
are tested.

BTW as bad as the Eclipse startup time is its not the end of the world 5-12
secs on my machine (guess it depends on what Windows has cached).
